newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan, South Africa talk reaches some concensus.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan, South Africa talk reaches some concensus.

text.p: Taiwan said on Saturday it had reached consensus with South Africa on certain issues in a third round of talks to negotiate their future relations after Pretoria switches ties to the island's rival China later this year.
A foreign ministry statement said the talks were held in Taipei on Friday and Saturday between South Africa's deputy foreign minister Aziz Pahad and Taiwan's deputy foreign minister C. J. Chen.
Taipei said further talks were due.
"Both sides reached consensus on certain issues and agreed that discussions on other aspects will be continued," the statement
Taiwan has repeatedly said it hopes to maintain high-level contacts with South Africa after Pretoria and Beijing normalise ties.
President Nelson Mandela said in November 1996 that Pretoria would cut diplomatic ties with Nationalist-ruled Taiwan and recognise the island's communist rival by the end of 1997.
Taipei responded by postponing all aid projects and treaties.

Taiwan's foreign minister John Chang recently said the island would consider resuming suspended economic cooperation programmes and direct flights after the sides reach agreement on the nature of bilateral ties.

South Africa is the largest of only 30 countries -- mostly underdeveloped states in central America and Africa -- that recognise Taiwan's exiled Republic of China government rather than the communist mainland's People's Republic.

Beijing, which has viewed Taiwan as a renegade province since a civil war split them in 1949, insists the island is ineligible for foreign ties and has tightened a diplomatic squeeze on Taipei in its quest to bring Taiwan under mainland rule.
